review_title: This place will set your career back
pros: Opportunities to work across in a cross functional capacity
cons: Competent faculty/staff have left in droves High turnover due to burnout, poor salary, meager benefits, dysfunctional leadership, limited insight into a business model that can survive declining enrollment, poor retention, and ROI

pros: Good colleagues and ready availability of administration to talk and listen to concerns
cons: College is financially struggling too much to pay people competitive salaries and the constant refrain is decrease spending

pros: Great colleagues, students are respectful of diverse viewpoints
cons: Low salary for region, salary freeze

pros: community, excellent students, gorgeous campus
cons: The pay and benefits did not match the workload. If I worked at another nearby school, I would likely receive higher pay and similar perks. Despite working extremely hard, the low salary and cost-saving culture of "do more with less" left me feeling undervalued. I believe the administration lacks a clear understanding of student and staff needs and priorities, and too often spends money on questionable initiatives.

pros: There is a real sense of community working at Stonehill. The work provides a good work/life balance and the benefits are good.
cons: The pay is not the most competitive.

review_title: Toxic work environment, terrible finances, might not survive
pros: Boston, academic environment, friendly students
cons: Long years of financial problems and the resulting veering between possible solutions means employees are overburdened, stressed out, and just waiting until their numbers come up for retirement or layoff. Conflicts between departments are high. The top management is heavy with incompetent people. We do not have enough faculty to teach courses; however, they continue to hire more highly-paid upper managers which does not add any value to the university. The situation is so worse that the university admitted almost all students who submitted an application. We have 50% more incoming students this year than our capacity. We do not have faculty to teach those extra class sessions. The university intentionally misrepresents the situation to new hires especially new faculty. Here is an advice from someone who spend most of his adult life in this university: Do not even waste your time to be interviewed by this university. Current faculty are leaving. The education quality is all-time-low as most faculty started not to care about students. The pay is so low and top management is determined to make it extremely low that they celebrate the inflation. The university spends more money on landscaping than faculty salaries. Run away!

job_title: Conference and Events Assistant in North Easton, MA
pros: Great staff, well paid, opportunity for OT
cons: There are no cons here.

review_title: Stay away!!! You have been warned
pros: Nice to be in an academic environment.
cons:
Very low Salary. 
Exploitative Management.
They ask you to teach 5 courses per semester without extra money. 3/3 course load is a joke here. 
The situation is so miserable that I know a faculty that start to work as an uber driver in summer. Almost everyone that I happen to know very well is looking for another academic position. Faculty is so overloaded with extra courses that they cannot research. Almost all faculty has a second job to put food on the table and pay the rent. Exploitation in this university is at record-level. If you are looking for underpaid, and unpaid faculty position that will make you mentally ill, Stonehill is an excellent choice. This is a titanic already started sinking. Joining Stonehill College was my biggest career mistake. I am writing this review so that fellow scholars should not make this mistake.

pros: Beautiful campus, median pay for the area
cons: If you are new here (didn’t go here, or haven’t worked here for forever), it’s very hard to be respected.

pros: Campus, students, academic life, colleagues
cons: burn out, incompetent management, low salary, high expectations, lack of resources, dishonest management.

pros: Close to Boston metropolitan area.
cons: Terrible pay for employees, mandatory overtimes, extra service/coursework with no pay, crowded classes, very little room for growth. Work-life balance is horrible because Stonehill College strongly believes the lives of all the employees revolve around the college.

pros: Great people, encouraging environment, I have fun at work. Pay is on par with other librarian positions in MA.
cons: Health insurance is not the best, administration moves relatively slowly.

pros: Flexible course scheduling for part timers
cons: Difficult to work with supervisors, often disorganized

review_title: No academic has a future here.
pros: Collegial coworkers and students generally pleasant to work with.
cons: Where to begin? Administration does not honor faculty startup agreements. They also promote and award faculty that are known to discriminate and plagiarize. Additionally, the College has implemented a set of policies where the burden of downside market/enrollment risk is placed on the shoulders of faculty and staff, while the benefits of all upside risk are transferred to administration. Leaderships' ability to communicate is also woefully inadequate, and they have no forward vision other than "cut operating costs." Faculty morale is at an all-time low, and many are quitting. There is significant risk that Stonehill will not survive the great demographic cliff coming in 2025 and 2026.

review_title: Great place to work but no way to advance
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Easton, MA
pros: Great community, beautiful campus, benefits
cons: No way to advance, there is no budget for raises or professional development opportunities.

job_title: Assistant Professor in North Easton, MA
pros: The colleagues who actually work with students are some of the kindest people you could ever find. There is truly a culture of respect amongst the faculty here.
cons:
The institution is exploitative of faculty labor and expects employees to work for wages that are not livable if you have a family or other expenses. Faculty salaries are well below the median income for the county and have been stagnant for the last several years. Early career faculty are being hurt by this and further hurt by the lack of other support structures at the institution to help them do their job effectively. 

If the college doesn't change the way they do business and soon they will continue to have trouble retaining teaching talent. The college views faculty as expendable annual term contract employees. Glorified adjuncts with health insurance. 

If you are considering taking a job here as a young professional think twice.

pros: I really like my department and the students.
cons: Faculty and admin seem to be in conflict.

pros: Stonehill attracts dedicated and loyal employees who form a tight-knit, compassionate community.  Stonehill faculty and staff find a true vocation in higher education and constantly strive to improve quality and expand knowledge and skills.  Stonehill tends to promote from within, so it's a great place for new professionals.
cons: Stonehill's familial atmosphere can sometimes feel too familial--with some of the issues associated with intense family dynamics, indirect communication patterns, and resistance to cultural change.
